pages.text: Nilpenia rossi comes from the Upper Ediacaran, with fossils found in the Flinders Ranges, South Australia. It is a branching lifeform, that could grow up to 30 cm in diameter, and possibly partook in sediment feeding, sitting within the sediment itself. The generic name derives from the place 'Nilpena', near to where it was was found. The specific name derives from the forename of Ross Fargher, who aided in the conservation of Nilpenia's fossils.
